p: According to Pliny the Elder (1st c. AD), the name A. dracunculus L., a diminutive of the Latin word “draco” – dragon (Gr. δράκων), dracunculus–a small dragon, was given to this plant because of its serpentine rhizomes ( Plinii Secundii, 1845). It was supposed to protect against snakebite when carried on one’s body or imbibed as a drink, and its juice was used in ear diseases. The name A. dracunculus might also be a distorted version of the Arabic name for tarragon, i.e. tharchum, from which the synonyms tarchon, tarcon and torchun are derived ( Rejewski, 1996).
